G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, and G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit and the events giving rise to this action occurred within the judicial district of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, and G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit and the events giving rise to this action occurred within the judicial district of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 9.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 9, as the cause of action arose in Brockton, Massachusetts.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity that undertakes the care and supervision of a child owes a duty to act as a reasonable person under the circumstances to protect that child from foreseeable harm. See Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (1983); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The excerpt is a dissent focused on proximate cause rather than on the existence or scope of the duty, and it does not itself discuss the standard of care for entities undertaking care and supervision of a child. However, Mullins v. Pine Manor College as a whole is a leading Massachusetts case recognizing that a college that undertakes to provide housing and security owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to protect its resident students from foreseeable criminal acts. Thus, while this passage does not address the proposition, the case itself supports the stated duty principle by analogy to custodial relationships such as care/supervision of minors.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: Because the provided text is solely Justice O’Connor’s dissent on causation, it does not contain the majority’s articulation of the duty of care. In the full opinion, the court explains that Pine Manor owed its resident students a duty to take reasonable measures to protect them against foreseeable criminal acts on campus, recognizing an obligation arising from the college’s undertaking to provide housing and security.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity that undertakes the care and supervision of a child owes a duty to act as a reasonable person under the circumstances to protect that child from foreseeable harm. See Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (1983); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: Glidden v. Maglio is a negligence and statutory-violation case focused on causation and, secondarily, on whether the defendant owed a duty as landowner/employer of an independent contractor. The court expressly declines to decide whether any duty of care existed, resolving the case solely on lack of evidence of causation. The opinion does not address, recognize, or articulate a specific duty of those undertaking the care and supervision of a child to protect that child from foreseeable harm, so it does not support the child‑supervision proposition for which it is cited.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The motion judge found that the plaintiffs had not shown the requisite control necessary to impose a duty on the defendant. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.”

Wallace v. Wilson, 292 Mass. 251 (1935).proposition: A duty of supervision arises when children are entrusted to the care, custody, and control of another. See Wallace v. Wilson, 292 Mass. 251 (1935); McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1105 (1989).
Wallace v. Wilson, 292 Mass. 251 (1935).support_reasoning: The opinion in Wallace v. Wilson concerns proximate cause and damages in an automobile negligence case involving an adult pedestrian. It does not discuss the entrustment of children to another’s care, custody, or control, nor any resulting duty of supervision. Using this case as authority for a supervision duty when children are entrusted to another is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the text of the decision.
Wallace v. Wilson, 292 Mass. 251 (1935).relevant_excerpt: All arise out of the same incident and are founded on alleged negligence of the defendant in so operating his automobile as to strike the intestate while she was crossing a public way on foot. ... The exception to the charge in the light of the medical testimony raises the question whether the injury which by reason of the negligence of the defendant came to the intestate could under the law have been found to be the proximate cause of her death.

McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 11.raw_text: McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1105 (1989)
McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 11.proposition: A duty of supervision arises when children are entrusted to the care, custody, and control of another. See Wallace v. Wilson, 292 Mass. 251 (1935); McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1105 (1989).
McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 11.support_reasoning: The opinion deals solely with timeliness of a request for retrial based on when notice of judgment is received and imputed receipt through a law firm employee. It does not involve children, custodial relationships, or any duty of supervision. Thus, McDonald v. Lavery provides no authority for the proposition that a duty of supervision arises when children are entrusted to the care, custody, and control of another; its citation for that proposition is misplaced or erroneous.
McDonald v. Lavery, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 11.relevant_excerpt: In the circumstances presented by this case, G. L. c. 231, § 104, as amended through St. 1986, c. 278, § 2, provided that a party seeking a retrial in the Superior Court must file “an entry fee . . . and bond within ten days after notice of the decision or finding [of the District Court].” It has long been established that notice is given, in the absence of an express contrary provision, when it is received by the person to whom it is directed.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant breached its duty of care by allowing a hazardous and unsupervised game to continue, by failing to provide adequate staffing, and by ignoring explicit warnings from participating children. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (foreseeability of harm central to negligence); Framingham v. Pizzano, 308 Mass. 76 (1941).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: Jupin v. Kask concerns a homeowner’s duty and potential negligence for failing to ensure safe storage of firearms where a violent, mentally unstable person has unsupervised access to the premises. It does not involve a defendant allowing a hazardous and unsupervised *game* to continue, inadequate staffing, or ignoring children’s warnings; those concepts are absent from the opinion. While Jupin does emphasize foreseeability as central to negligence, using it here to support a claim about supervision of games, staffing, and child warnings would be an inaccurate extension of the holding and context.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. … Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct.’”

Framingham v. Pizzano, 308 Mass. 76 (194.proposition: Defendant breached its duty of care by allowing a hazardous and unsupervised game to continue, by failing to provide adequate staffing, and by ignoring explicit warnings from participating children. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (foreseeability of harm central to negligence); Framingham v. Pizzano, 308 Mass. 76 (1941).
Framingham v. Pizzano, 308 Mass. 76 (194.case_name: City of Boston v. Boston Port Development Co.
Framingham v. Pizzano, 308 Mass. 76 (194.support_reasoning: The opinion in Framingham v. Pizzano is a tax foreclosure case dealing with the validity of tax titles, adequacy of statutory tax demands, assessment methods, and taxation of flats. It does not address negligence, duty of care, supervision of hazardous activities, staffing, or foreseeability of harm to children. Citing this case for the proposition about a defendant’s duty of care in supervising hazardous games is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the holding or reasoning of the opinion.
Framingham v. Pizzano, 308 Mass. 76 (194.relevant_excerpt: “This is a petition to foreclose rights of redemption under certain tax titles, acquired by the petitioner in 1934, for nonpayment of the real estate taxes assessed for the year 1932 on ten parcels of real estate… The respondent’s only other ground of objection is that the assessments of parcels 1, 2 and 3 were illegal ‘on account of the fact that each of said parcels is land located between high water and low water, generally called flats.’”

Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.raw_text: Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37 (2009)
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.proposition: Foreseeability of injury from unsupervised rough play by minors is clear; Defendant’s failure to supervise directly caused the injuries suffered by Plaintiff’s son. See Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37 (2009); Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002).
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.support_reasoning: Leavitt does not involve minors, rough play, or supervision duties; it concerns whether a hospital owed a duty and proximate cause to a third-party police officer injured while responding to an accident involving a sedated adult patient. The SJC ultimately finds no duty to the plaintiff and specifically holds that his injuries were outside the scope of foreseeable risk arising from the hospital’s alleged negligence. This runs counter to the proposition that foreseeability of the injury is clear and that the defendant’s failure to supervise directly caused the injury, so the case does not support the stated proposition.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "The hospital also claims that it should not be held liable on a separate, independent ground: the injury to Leavitt was not 'caused' by any action on its part. We agree. Leavitt’s injury was not 'caused' by the hospital because it falls outside the scope of foreseeable risk arising from any negligent conduct that would make the hospital’s alleged misconduct tortious.... While a third party nonpatient directly injured by a medicated patient who drives an automobile from a hospital may be within the scope of foreseeable risk, a police officer injured in an accident in which the patient is not involved is outside that scope."

Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.raw_text: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002)
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.proposition: Foreseeability of injury from unsupervised rough play by minors is clear; Defendant’s failure to supervise directly caused the injuries suffered by Plaintiff’s son. See Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37 (2009); Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002).
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.case_name: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns foreseeability of injury from unsupervised rough play by minors and a defendant’s duty to supervise, but Coughlin involves negligent hiring/supervision of an adult employee who murdered a child, and the court held there was no duty because the harm was not reasonably foreseeable. The opinion actually limits foreseeability and rejects imposing a duty to protect members of the public in these circumstances, rather than recognizing a clear, direct causal link from failure to supervise. It therefore does not support the claimed proposition and in fact cuts against it on foreseeability and duty.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “The most important consideration in determining whether a special relationship exists between a plaintiff and a defendant is whether the ‘defendant reasonably could foresee that he would be expected to take affirmative action to protect the plaintiff and could anticipate harm to the plaintiff from the failure to do so.’ … [A] background check would not have provided any additional information that would have enabled Titus & Bean to reasonably foresee that Kelley posed a threat to members of the public at or near 385R Court Street… As matter of law, Titus & Bean owed the victim no legal duty.”

Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.raw_text: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. at 639
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.proposition: Plaintiff and his son suffered actual damages, including medical expenses, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of consortium. See Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. at 639; Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 557 (1982).
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.case_name: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics is focused on duty, foreseeability, and summary judgment in a wrongful death/negligent hiring context. It does not discuss or enumerate the plaintiff’s or his son’s actual damages such as medical expenses, pain and suffering, emotional distress, or loss of consortium. The cited page (639) concerns duty and foreseeability, not damages, so the case does not provide authority for the specific damages proposition stated.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: "Under Massachusetts law, to prove a cause of action founded upon negligence, the plaintiff must satisfy the elements of duty, breach, causation, and damages. See Bacon v. Federal Kemper Life Assur. Co., 400 Mass. 850, 853 (1987)."

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 55.proposition: Plaintiff and his son suffered actual damages, including medical expenses, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of consortium. See Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. at 639; Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 557 (1982).
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 55.support_reasoning: Payton is a class certification and tort doctrine case about emotional distress, prenatal injury, and DES liability; it does not involve a plaintiff and his son, nor does it discuss an itemized list of actual damages such as medical expenses, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of consortium. The cited page (at 557) concerns requirements for negligent infliction of emotional distress, not a damages catalog. Thus, Payton does not support the specific proposition about the types of actual damages suffered by a plaintiff and his son.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 55.relevant_excerpt: "In summary, we should that a plaintiff in order to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress must prove the following: (1) negligence; (2) emotional distress; (3) causations; (4) physical harm manifested by objective symptomatology; and 95) that a reasonable person would have suffered emotional distress under the circumstances of the case." (386 Mass. at 557).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 85A\u201385Q.proposition: Plaintiff brings this action individually and on behalf of his minor child, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 85A–85Q, and G.L. c. 231, § 6D, seeking compensation for injuries proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6D.proposition: Plaintiff brings this action individually and on behalf of his minor child, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 85A–85Q, and G.L. c. 231, § 6D, seeking compensation for injuries proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence.
